com.github.robtimus.net.ip

Class IPAddressFormatter<IP extends IPAddress<?>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.robtimus.net.ip.IPAddressFormatter<IP>
  • Type Parameters:
    IP - The supported type of IP address.

    public abstract class IPAddressFormatter<IP extends IPAddress<?>>
extends Object
    Formatter for printing and parsing IP addresses.
    Author:
    Rob Spoor

        Returns:

        Throws:

      • parse

        public abstract IP parse(CharSequence source)
                  throws ParseException
        Parses a CharSequence to an IP address.
        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        Returns:
        The parsed IP address.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the given CharSequence is null.
        ParseException - If the CharSequence could not be parsed to an IP address.

      • parse

        public abstract IP parse(CharSequence source,
                         ParsePosition position)
        Attempts to parse a CharSequence to an IP address. Parsing starts at the current index of the given ParsePosition.

        If parsing succeeds, the given ParsePosition's index is updated to the index after the last character that was used for parsing. The updated position can be used as a starting point for other parsing.

        If parsing fails, the given ParsePosition's index is not modified, but its error index is set to the index of the character that caused parsing to fail.

        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        position - The ParsePosition to update as described.
        Returns:
        The parsed IP address if parsing succeeded, or null if parsing fails.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the given CharSequence or ParsePosition is null.

      • tryParse

        public abstract Optional<IP> tryParse(CharSequence source)
        Attempts to parse a CharSequence to an IP address.
        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        Returns:
        An Optional with the parsed IP address if parsing succeeded, or Optional#empty() if parsing fails.

      • parseToBytes

        public abstract byte[] parseToBytes(CharSequence source)
                             throws ParseException
        Parses a CharSequence to an IP address.
        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        Returns:
        A byte array representing the parsed IP address.
        Throws:
        ParseException - If the CharSequence could not be parsed to an IP address.

      • parseToBytes

        public abstract byte[] parseToBytes(CharSequence source,
                                    ParsePosition position)
        Attempts to parse a CharSequence to an IP address. Parsing starts at the current index of the given ParsePosition.

        If parsing succeeds, the given ParsePosition's index is updated to the index after the last character that was used for parsing. The updated position can be used as a starting point for other parsing.

        If parsing fails, the given ParsePosition's index is not modified, but its error index is set to the index of the character that caused parsing to fail.

        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        position - The ParsePosition to update as described.
        Returns:
        A byte array representing the parsed IP address if parsing succeeded, or null if parsing fails.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If the given CharSequence or ParsePosition is null.

      • tryParseToBytes

        public abstract Optional<byte[]> tryParseToBytes(CharSequence source)
        Attempts to parse a CharSequence to an IP address.
        Parameters:
        source - The CharSequence to parse.
        Returns:
        An Optional with a byte array representing the parsed IP address if parsing succeeded, or Optional#empty() if parsing fails.

      • ipv4

        public static IPAddressFormatter<IPv4Address> ipv4()
        Returns a formatter for printing and parsing IPv4 addresses.
        Returns:
        A formatter for printing and parsing IPv4 addresses.

      • ipv6WithDefaults

        public static IPAddressFormatter<IPv6Address> ipv6WithDefaults()
        Returns a formatter for printing and parsing IPv6 addresses. When printing IPv6 addresses, it will use a short format that will omit the longest consecutive section of zeroes. For example, it will print ::1 or :: and not 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 or 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0.
        Returns:
        A formatter for printing and parsing IPv6 addresses.

      • anyVersionWithDefaults

        public static IPAddressFormatter<IPAddress<?>> anyVersionWithDefaults()
        Returns a formatter for printing and parsing IP addresses of any version. When printing IPv6 addresses, it will use a short format that will omit the longest consecutive section of zeroes. For example, it will print ::1 or :: and not 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 or 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0.
        Returns:
        A formatter for printing and parsing IP addresses of any version.

      • ipv6

        public static IPAddressFormatter.Builder<IPv6Address> ipv6()
        Returns a new builder for formatters for printing and parsing IPv6 addresses.

        Note: the builder specific settings are only relevant for printing. If only parsing is required, use ipv6WithDefaults() instead.

        Returns:
        A new builder for formatters for printing and parsing IPv6 addresses.

      • anyVersion

        public static IPAddressFormatter.Builder<IPAddress<?>> anyVersion()
        Returns a new builder for formatters for printing and parsing IP addresses of any version.

        Note: the builder specific settings are only relevant for printing. If only parsing is required, use ipv6WithDefaults() instead.

        Returns:
        A new builder for formatters for printing and parsing IP addresses of any version.
